qas.question: What is the goal of the NIBRS?

answers.text: address limitations inherent in UCR data

qas.question: What is the NIBRS used for?
What does the NIBRS collect information on?
Does the NIBRS system or UCR system have more detailed data?
What system do Canadian law enforcement agencies use?
What agencies do not generate NIBRS data?

plausible_answers.text: 46 specific crimes grouped in 22 offense categories

qas.question: What offers less detail than the UCR system?
How many law enforcement agencies submit UCR data?

context: The <b5_0>National Incident Based Reporting System<b5_0/> (NIBRS) crime statistics system aims to <a0_0>address limitations inherent in UCR data<a0_0/>. The system is used by law enforcement agencies in <a1_0>the United States<a1_0/> for <a2_0>collecting and reporting data<a2_0/> on <a3_0>crimes<a3_0/>. <b6_0>Local, state, and federal agencies<b6_0/> generate NIBRS data from their records management systems. Data is collected on every incident and arrest in the Group A offense category. The Group A offenses are <b7_0>46 specific crimes grouped in 22 offense categories<b7_0/>. Specific facts about these offenses are gathered and reported in the NIBRS system. In addition to the Group A offenses, eleven Group B offenses are reported with only the arrest information. The <a4_0><b8_0>NIBRS<b8_0/><a4_0/> system is in greater detail than the summary-based UCR system. As of 2004, <b9_0>5,271<b9_0/> law enforcement agencies submitted NIBRS data. That amount represents 20% of the United States population and 16% of the crime statistics data collected by the FBI.
